physDesc.p: Four pages typewritten in black ink. Address given for H. D. in the top left corner of the first page: Mrs. Richard Aldington c/o Manager, Lloyd’s Bank, 67 Kingsway, London W.C.2. England. Unsigned. Date was changed from March 20, 1923 to March 30, 1923; the change was made in pencil. At the end of the letter, "Draft according to exchange" was added in pencil.

editorialDecl.p: This letter contains references to the following:

body.p: I believe I have never answered your letter of last October, and I am sure I never thanked you for your Christmas card, all of which deserves mya sincere apology. But really, my dear, I find letters exceedingly hard to write, with this terrible Keats book taking all my time and all my energy. Perhaps, when it is finished, I shall burst into a perfect flame of correspondence. But now I have something most important to write you, and my only regret at not writing earlier is that you may have heard it first from Ferris Greenslet. Houghton Mifflin will take your book. I gave Ferris your London bank address, as he was very anxious to see you when he went over, which he did about three weeks ago. I told him I had no idea whether you were in England or were going to be there, and I think he was not going on the Continent, but probably he will succeed in reaching you somehow and you can talk over the terms he suggests, which I strongly advise you to accept, although they are not calculated to turn your royalties into a mine of gold.

My experience with Houghton Mifflin is that they make very severe contracts with their authors, but that they live absolutely up to the letter of them and frequently interpret them to the author’s advantage. It iswas just the other way with Macmillan, who made what seemed like an extremely lenient contract, and then crept up on it on all points. As I told Marianne Moore that Houghton Mifflin had accepted it, and as she is more prompt in her correspondence than I, I think you may have heard the news from her as well as from Ferris.

My only wish that you had not sent your new poetry volume to Henry Holt, as my experience, and that of all the authors with whom I have talked, is that it is better to be published by one firm, and not to scatter one’s books among a number of firms, for in that case no firm takes the same interest in you as they would do if they were your sole publishers. I think Houghton Mifflin are beginning to see the error of their ways in not accepting "Hymen" and having all your books in their hands. Being a perfectly honest person, I was compelled to tell Ferris that Marianne Moore had told me, on the whole, I think it was Louis Untermeyer who told me; not Marianne Moore that Henry Holt had taken your new poems, but he must want to publish your things as in spite of this he is willing to take your essays, which shows he must want them a good deal. If you do see him or if you do correspond with him, I hope you will agree to give him first chance on whatever new books you have, as I think he is realizing more and more that you are a very important person in this poetry renaissance, and that it would be a good thing for his firm to be your publishers.

Here is the little pittance for our half-yearly royalties on the "Imagist Anthologies." They sell os little now that the few copies we have left of each volume seem to go on forever, but, as I have long since given orders that they are not to be reprinted, I suppose these liter doles of five and ten cent pieces will end in time. They report that there are 25 copies of the 1915, 23 copies of the 1916, and 31 copies of the 1917 volumes left over.

I should have sent you this money last month, but I have been away for six weeks touring the Middle West and giving seventeen lectures. It was a most interesting experience, but a little too strenuous for me. I came home with a wretched cold which it has taken me an age to throw off, but I am all right now.

I am not coming to London this Spring as I had hoped, because I have got the Keats book ready for the press and they are very anxious to publish it next Autumn. I hope that I may get it done in time, but the mere manual labour of writing seems to make that doubtful, though I have not said as much to the publishers. However, I am getting on swimmingly, and, if I could write more hours a day and if there were more days between now and Autumn, I could certainly finish it in time. As it is now, it is a mere question of how long it will take to put it down on paper, for this book is now entirely crystallized in my mind, and my stacks of notes are now numbered and in order so that I have no difficulty in using them. Two years is a long time to meditate on a book and do the preliminary work on it, and that I have reached the stage of writing is almost an intoxication to me after the drudgery which preceded it.

I heard of you last from Winifred Bryher, although she said she had not seen you. She and McAlmon seem to be getting along all right. I cannot quite make out how. Marianne Moore seemed to think it was a marriage of convenience and that they were not living together as husband and wife. Personally, from Winifred’s letters, I should doubt this. I should doubt it all more from her poems, and I do not know whether Marianne Moore knows any more about it than I do, as neither of us have seen them since they were married. I wish you would give me your opinion on the subject; in confidence, of course.

If there is any more I can do for you at any time to forward your work here, or anything else that ou would like, you know you can always command me. I thought your poems in the "Miscellany" were particularly fine. I wonder how Aiken’s "Anthology" is getting on in London. The book has had long reviews; scarcely, I think, favourable ones. The animosity of the English press toward American poetry is one of the things that prove how extremely vital and interesting American poetry is, I believe.

Well, my dear, this rambling around must end. I will try not to be so dilatory in answering your next letter, which is a hint that you write me at once and tell me your news, because, like most bad correspondents, I like getting letters.
body.closer: Ada sends her love, and I am as always, Affectionately yours,
